question: What does a star, a large astronomical body, emit through nuclear reactions?

content.source_1: Stars are massive, luminous astronomical bodies held together by their own gravity and are categorized as celestial objects.
content.source_2: In main-sequence stars, nuclear fusion in the core converts hydrogen into helium and releases energy that emerges as starlight.
content.source_3: Most stars spend the majority of their lifetimes on the main sequence.
content.source_4: White dwarfs and neutron stars—objects commonly referred to as stars—do not sustain core nuclear fusion; they shine from residual heat or non-fusion processes such as synchrotron radiation.
content.source_5: In astronomical usage, the term “star” encompasses both hydrogen‑burning stars and compact stellar remnants like white dwarfs and neutron stars.
content.source_6: Hot stellar remnants can emit visible and ultraviolet light purely via thermal radiation, without any ongoing nuclear reactions.
